info.game_comments:
Ashok Poozhikunnel game 5.
Kristin Morgan game 1.

(1, 1).clue: In 2004 a U.S. law named in part for this type of unwelcome e-mail took effect to prohibit deceptive subject lines

(2, 1).clue: There's a canal named this in Mesa County, Colorado, a long way from the famous one in New York State

(3, 1).clue: In 2011 Josh Elliott of ESPN became news reader for this ABC show that starts many people's day

(5, 1).clue: One set of rules in this test of strength says if the grip comes apart, the 2 hands will be strapped together

(6, 1).clue: He let his theory evolve for 20 years before going public in 1858

(1, 2).clue: A set of operating rules for computer information exchange; it can also mean proper diplomatic etiquette

(2, 2).clue: The U.S. has 110 hospitals named for this helpful New Testament fella from Luke 10

(3, 2).clue: Aaron Sorkin created Will McAvoy, anchorman with a conscience, for this HBO series

(4, 2).clue: Don't do it to your neighbor's stuff, warn the 10 Commandments

(5, 2).clue: Contest in which old automobiles are intentionally crashed into each other until only one is left running

(6, 2).clue: In the 1660s, with Cambridge closed by plague, he went home & started inventing calculus

(1, 3).clue: I'm sorry, contestants, it was the name of the murderous computer in "2001: A Space Odyssey"

(2, 3).clue: No shortage of U.S. islands called this; there are 162 besides the one that's home to Queens & Massapequa

(3, 3).clue: A new bio of this beloved CBS anchor says he bugged a committee room at the 1952 Republican Convention

(4, 3).clue: The Sting Ray was one model of this classic transport

(5, 3).clue: This Olympic event is also called water ballet

(6, 3).clue: This 19th century chemist saved France's beer, wine & silk industries

(1, 4).clue: In 1961 Les Earnest created the first program of this type, now a word processing tool, & yes, computer, his name is Les with 1 S

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Idaho.)  This Idaho ski resort was developed by the Union Pacific Railroad & named by a press agent who brought Hollywood stars to popularize the area

(3, 4).clue: In 2012 she succeeded Ann Curry as co-anchor of the "Today" show

(4, 4).clue: Catlike critter prized for its musk

(5, 4).clue: In the '80s Photon was a chain of venues for this game inspired by "Star Wars"

(6, 4).clue: In 1957 this Danish physicist became the first recipient of the USA's Atoms for Peace Award

(1, 5).clue: WinZip is a popular tool for doing this, reducing file size to store or transfer more data

(2, 5).clue: Warm Springs, Georgia's airport is named for him

(3, 5).clue: We're glad this CNN show hosted by Candy Crowley isn't just on once a year in January

(4, 5).clue: Oy, it means to complain or someone who complains a lot

(5, 5).clue: A saying in this circus activity is "the trouble is that the balls go where you throw them"

(6, 5).clue: After discovering Uranus, he wanted to name it for King George III

(1, 1).clue: Robert LeRoy Parker was the real name of this outlaw & colleague of the Sundance Kid

(2, 1).clue: Oregon State basketball coach Craig Robinson, an MBA from the U. of Chicago, has this very famous brother-in-law

(3, 1).clue: The Arctic has this type of "ice cap"

(4, 1).clue: Nicholas Hoult & Kelsey Grammer have played Dr. Hank McCoy in films about these marvelous mutants

(5, 1).clue: "We Will Rock You", playing in the West End since 2002, features the music of this group

(6, 1).clue: Skirt steak is great for this sizzling southwest treat that comes with tortillas, peppers & onions

(1, 2).clue: The FBI said the ma of these "bloody" brothers was part of the gang, but pa George was a shiftless beneficiary

(2, 2).clue: Agamemnon & Menelaus were both brothers & brothers-in-law: they wed sisters Clytemnestra & this Trojan beauty

(3, 2).clue: 4-letter word of disdain; when doubled, it's a verb meaning to dismiss

(4, 2).clue: Lauren Tewes welcomed guests aboard as cruise director Julie McCoy on this long-running ABC series

(5, 2).clue: In summer 2011 Ralph Fiennes took to the stage as Prospero in this play

(6, 2).clue: A popular '70s gift was a pot for this dish of melted cheese & forks to dip the bread into it

(1, 3).clue: The Younger brothers, standing, formed an outlaw alliance with these brothers seated in the photo here

(2, 3).clue: This Scot, the winner of the 2012 Indy 500, is the son-in-law of country superstar Naomi Judd

(3, 3).clue: The Maharishi sometimes used this word as part of his name

(4, 3).clue: Captain Bill McCoy's bootlegging ship is anchored off the New Jersey coast in the first scene of this HBO series

(5, 3).clue: In summer 2012 this play based on a movie about 2 British athletes at the 1924 Olympics was off & running

(6, 3).clue: Focaccia & naan are types of this

(2, 4).clue: Social philosopher William Godwin was dad-in-law to this romantic poet

(3, 4).clue: This city name comes from an Illinois Native American word for the wild leek

(4, 4).clue: Leonard was the first name of Dr. McCoy, made famous by this actor in the 1960s

(5, 5).clue: A 1991 production of "Three Sisters" featured these 2 daughters of Sir Michael, & their niece Jemma

(6, 5).clue: Eaten raw or cooked, this fern is named for its resemblance to part of a violin

(0, 0).clue: These 2 world capitals are separated by only 250 miles of land & less than 1 degree of latitude, at 59º 17' & 59º 57' N.
